title: Month's worth of rain to fall in a few hours as Britain braces for storms
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

A month’s worth of rain is set to fall as heavy downpours sweep across the UK over the next 30 hours.

Danger to life alerts are in place across parts of Wales and northern England where up to four inches of rain is expected over the peaks of Snowdonia and the Brecon Beacons.

The predicted deluge would equal the average for the whole of October.

Weather warnings remain in place across most of Wales, along with Cumbria and the Pennines in the northwest of England stretching south to the Peak District from Friday afternoon through to 3pm on Saturday.

The Met Office warned of potential flooding to homes and businesses, travel chaos as trains and buses are hit with delays and cancellations and communities being cut off by flooded roads.

A month’s worth of rainfall could fall in just 30 hours (Picture: SWNS)

The downpours could cause chaos with journeys disrupted and communities cut off by flooded roads (Picture: SWNS)

Weather warnings are in place for Friday and Saturday across much of Wales along with northern England and the southwest (Picture: Met Office)

Six flood alerts were issued by the Environment Agency covering the Lower Avon, lower River Soar, minor watercourses in north Kesteven, Rase and Upper Ancholme, the River Evenlode, the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock and the River Mole.

Their five-day flood risk for England and Wales states: ‘Local flooding is possible from rivers and surface water across Wales and parts of northern, central and south-west England later on Friday and on Saturday.

‘Local river flooding may continue through Sunday and into Monday on some longer, slower-responding rivers. Properties may flood and there may be travel disruption.’

The Met Office’s yellow warnings state ‘there is a small chance that homes and businesses could be flooded, causing damage to some buildings’ while ‘fast flowing or deep floodwater’ could pose a ‘danger to life’.

Journeys could be hit by delays and cancellations due to flooding while there is also a ‘small chance that some communities become cut off by flooded roads’.

The Scottish Highlands might even see snow (Picture: AFP)

Northern England and Wales are expected to be particularly wet (Picture: Getty Images)

The downpours could cause ‘issues with travel disruption’ (Picture: SWNS)

Forecaster Aidan McGivern said there will be a marked contrast in outlook between the north and south heading into the weekend.

Northern parts of Scotland could see ‘very blustery winds, frequent showers and 70mph gusts of wind’ while snow is expected to fall across the highlands.

‘That could cause flooding and by lunchtime on Saturday issues with travel disruption and so on,’ Mr McGivern added.

Moving south he said it will likely ‘feel miserable under heavy rain across central areas’, with northern England and Wales ‘particularly wet’.

‘It will be a wet morning for western parts of England as well as Wales over the hilltops, especially with that rain which is heavy and persistent,’ Mr McGivern said.

He added that three-and-a-half inches of rain is ‘possible over the moors of the southwest’, with more than four-and-a-half coming down ‘over the mountains of Wales in some of the wetter spots’.

Other areas, including ‘some of the higher tops of the Pennines’, could see just over two-and-a-half inches or rain.

Advertisement

The October average rainfall for northern England is 3.96 inches while the average in Wales is 6.68 inches.

description: A month’s worth of rain is set to fall as heavy downpours sweep across the UK over the next 30 hours, the Met Office has said.
